questions.question: What does the 'Matrix of Hell' refer to in software deployment?

options.text: The difficulty of managing many applications across many different environments
A bug in the Docker Daemon
The high cost of cloud computing

questions.explanation: The 'Matrix of Hell' is the logistical challenge of ensuring every piece of software you build can run reliably across various servers, OS versions, and cloud providers.

questions.question: Which component is the 'brain' of Docker that manages images and containers?
questions.explanation: The Docker Daemon (dockerd) is the server-side component that listens for API requests and manages Docker objects like images, containers, networks, and volumes.

questions.question: What is the relationship between an Image and a Container?

options.text: An image is a running instance of a container
A container is a read-only template for an image
A container is a running instance of an image

questions.explanation: Think of an Image as a blueprint or recipe, and a Container as the actual building or dish created from that blueprint.

questions.question: Which command would you use to see containers that have finished running?
questions.explanation: The 'docker ps' command only shows running containers. Adding the '-a' (all) flag shows all containers, including those that are stopped or exited.
